title: TABLE Comparing the use of signing statements

content.description:
President and Term
 Signing Statements Issued
 Objections to Legislation Within the Signing Statement

Reagan (1981–1989)
 250
 86 (35%)

George H. W. Bush (1989–1993)
 228
 107 (47%)

Clinton (1993–2001)
 381
 70 (18%)

George W. Bush (2001–2009)
 161
 127 (79%)

Source: Table based on data from Todd Garvey, “Presidential Signing Statements: Constitutional and Institutional Implications,” CRS Report, published January 4, 2012, https://fas.org/sgp/crs/natsec/RL33667.pdf
content.question: Which of the following statements is most accurately supported by the data in the table?

choices.label: President Clinton greatly reduced the use of presidential signing statements compared with his predecessors.
While President George W. Bush issued fewer signing statements than President Clinton, his included more objections than President Clinton’s.
President Clinton’s brief access to the power of the line-item veto allowed him to issue fewer signing statements that raised concerns about legislation.
President George W. Bush was forced to issue more signing statements as a direct result of the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001.

content.answer: While President George W. Bush issued fewer signing statements than President Clinton, his included more objections than President Clinton’s.

skill.text: Skill 3.B: Describe patterns and trends in data.
